questions.question: Directed by James Cameron and starring Leonardo DiCaprio and Kate Winslet, this 1997 Oscar-winning film follows a doomed romance aboard a British ocean liner on its ill-fated maiden voyage.
This Swedish pop group, consisting of two couples, became one of the best-selling music acts of all time with hits like 'Dancing Queen,' 'Mamma Mia,' and 'Fernando.'
Led by quarterback Patrick Mahomes, this NFL franchise from Missouri won three Super Bowl championships between 2020 and 2024, establishing themselves as the dominant dynasty of the era.
The largest island in the Mediterranean Sea and an autonomous region of Italy, this volcanic island is home to Mount Etna — Europe's tallest and most active volcano.
This creamy dip, a staple of Mexican and Tex-Mex cuisine, is made primarily from mashed avocados, lime juice, cilantro, and salt, and is famously consumed in record quantities on Super Bowl Sunday.

This Netflix crime drama, set on the Lake of the Ozarks in Missouri, stars Jason Bateman as financial planner Marty Byrde, who is forced to launder money for a Mexican drug cartel after a scheme goes wrong.
Mirepoix is the aromatic flavor base made with what three ingredients?
The 2002 film 'The Rookie' sees Dennis Quaid portray real-life pitcher Jim Morris, who at age 35 made his major league debut for what team?
How many days does the Christian period of Lent last?
Known as 'The King of Pop,' this artist's 1982 album 'Thriller' remains the best-selling album of all time, with estimated sales of over 66 million copies worldwide.

This NBA franchise has won 17 championships — the most in league history — and has retired the jerseys of Kareem Abdul-Jabbar, Magic Johnson, and Kobe Bryant, whose numbers 8 and 24 both hang in its rafters.

The largest country in South America by both area and population, this Portuguese-speaking nation is home to the Amazon River basin and hosted both the 2014 FIFA World Cup and the 2016 Summer Olympics.

This 2008 Marvel film, starring Robert Downey Jr. as a billionaire weapons manufacturer who builds a powered suit of armor to escape captivity, launched what became the highest-grossing film franchise in history.
This soft Italian cheese, traditionally made from the milk of water buffaloes, is named from the Italian word meaning 'to cut off' and is most recognizable melted atop pizza.
This Corsican-born military genius rose to become Emperor of the French in 1804, conquered much of Europe, and introduced a legal code that still influences the laws of dozens of countries today.
The chemical symbol 'Au,' derived from the Latin word 'Aurum,' represents this precious metal with atomic number 79, long prized for its resistance to tarnish and its role as a monetary standard.

This HBO drama, which aired from 1999 to 2007, follows Tony Soprano, a New Jersey mob boss who attends weekly therapy sessions while juggling the pressures of organized crime and his suburban family life.

Nicknamed 'Air,' this Chicago Bulls shooting guard won six NBA championships in the 1990s, five regular-season MVP awards, and was named the greatest North American athlete of the 20th century by ESPN.
The capital of Japan and the world's most populous metropolitan area with over 37 million residents, this city hosted the Summer Olympics in both 1964 and 2021.
This British rock band, fronted by Freddie Mercury, released the 1975 song 'Bohemian Rhapsody' — a six-minute operatic rock epic that topped the UK singles chart twice, forty years apart.
The largest animal ever known to have lived on Earth, this marine mammal can grow up to 100 feet long and weigh 200 tons — its heart alone is roughly the size of a small car.

Voiced by Mike Myers, the titular hero of this 2001 DreamWorks animated film is a reclusive swamp-dwelling ogre who reluctantly teams with a talking donkey to rescue a princess from a tower guarded by a dragon.

This Japanese dish of thinly sliced raw protein — typically tuna or salmon — is served without rice and accompanied by soy sauce, wasabi, and pickled ginger, distinguishing it from its close relative sushi.

This surprise Japanese air attack on December 7, 1941 killed over 2,400 Americans and damaged or destroyed 19 naval vessels, prompting President Roosevelt to call it 'a date which will live in infamy.'

The largest organ of the human body by surface area, this outer covering accounts for roughly 16% of body weight, houses nerve endings that detect temperature and pain, and serves as the body's primary barrier against infection.

This pop star, born Stefani Germanotta in New York City, became a global phenomenon with her debut single 'Just Dance' in 2008 and later won an Oscar for Best Original Song for 'Shallow' from 'A Star Is Born.'

The first episode of this CBS reality competition, which has aired since 2000, drew 51 million viewers; contestants are isolated in a remote location and vote each other out one by one until a sole winner remains.
In tennis, a score of zero is called by this name — a term whose fun etymology often traces back to the French word for 'egg,' which visually resembles the numeral zero.
Home to the Great Wall, the Terracotta Army, and the Forbidden City, this East Asian country had the world's largest population until 2023 and remains the second-largest economy on Earth.

This 2009 James Cameron film — set on the lush alien moon Pandora — became the highest-grossing movie of all time at the time of its release and features a paraplegic Marine who bonds with a blue-skinned species called the Na'vi.
This rich emulsion sauce — made from egg yolks, melted butter, and lemon juice — is the hallmark of Eggs Benedict and is counted among the five classical French 'mother sauces.'

Signed on July 4, 1776, this document formally announced the separation of thirteen American colonies from Great Britain and includes the famous line 'We hold these truths to be self-evident, that all men are created equal.'

Plants absorb this greenhouse gas during photosynthesis to produce oxygen and sugars, while its rising concentration in Earth's atmosphere — largely from burning fossil fuels — is the primary driver of modern climate change.
This Houston-born singer and performer released the groundbreaking visual album 'Lemonade' in 2016 and has won more Grammy Awards than any other singer in history, cementing her reign as 'Queen Bey.'

This animated Fox sitcom, set in the fictional Rhode Island town of Quahog, follows the Griffin family — including the martini-drinking baby Stewie and the culturally literate talking dog Brian — and has aired since 1999.

This American swimmer from Baltimore won a record 28 Olympic medals — 23 of them gold — over four Games, including a stunning eight gold medals at the 2008 Beijing Olympics, making him the most decorated Olympian in history.

This boot-shaped country in southern Europe holds more UNESCO World Heritage Sites than any other nation and uniquely contains two independent countries — Vatican City and San Marino — entirely within its borders.

In this 2008 Christopher Nolan film, Heath Ledger's portrayal of the Joker earned a posthumous Oscar for Best Supporting Actor, helping the film become the first superhero movie to gross over $1 billion worldwide.
This buttery, flaky French breakfast pastry is created through a technique called 'lamination' — repeatedly folding dough with layers of butter — and is baked into a golden, crescent shape.

This ancient Roman amphitheater, completed around 80 AD and capable of holding up to 80,000 spectators, was the largest arena of its kind and hosted gladiatorial contests, animal hunts, and public executions.
On the Fahrenheit scale, water boils at sea level at this temperature — equivalent to 100 degrees Celsius — a key reference point embedded in American kitchens and science classrooms alike.
Formed in Dublin, Ireland in 1976, this rock band became one of the world's best-selling acts with anthems including 'With or Without You,' 'One,' and 'Sunday Bloody Sunday,' fronted by singer Bono.
This NBC mockumentary sitcom, starring Amy Poehler as the relentlessly optimistic deputy parks director Leslie Knope, is set in the fictional Indiana city of Pawnee and aired from 2009 to 2015.

Governed globally by FIFA and played by an estimated 250 million people across more than 200 countries, this is the world's most popular sport — known as 'football' nearly everywhere outside the United States.
This North African country is home to the Pyramids of Giza, the Great Sphinx, and the Nile River delta, and was the cradle of one of the world's earliest and longest-lasting civilizations.

In this 2014 Marvel film, a rag-tag team of cosmic misfits — including a talking raccoon named Rocket and a tree creature who can only say three words — join forces to protect the universe from a powerful villain.
This cured, spiced, and smoked beef — a centerpiece of New York City Jewish deli culture — is most famously served piled high on rye bread at Katz's Delicatessen on the Lower East Side.

Ratified in August 1920 after decades of activism by figures like Susan B. Anthony, this constitutional amendment guaranteed American women the right to vote — one of the most significant expansions of democracy in U.S. history.

This biological process, occurring in the chloroplasts of plant cells, converts sunlight, water, and carbon dioxide into glucose and oxygen, forming the foundation of nearly every food chain on Earth.

This singer-songwriter from Reading, Pennsylvania crossed over from country to pop and became the first artist to simultaneously occupy all top 10 spots on the Billboard Hot 100 with tracks from her 2022 album 'Midnights.'
This HBO anthology series, created by Mike White, follows wealthy guests and overworked staff at luxury resorts — first in Hawaii, then Sicily — and won 10 Emmy Awards for its debut season alone.

First held in 1903 and covering roughly 3,400 kilometers across 21 stages through the French Alps and Pyrenees, this annual bicycle race is the world's most prestigious and grueling endurance sports event.

This purpose-built city, chosen as a compromise between Sydney and Melbourne, became the capital of Australia in 1913 and is frequently overlooked by tourists who assume the capital is one of the country's coastal giants.
This 1994 Disney animated film, set in the Pride Lands of Africa, follows young Simba as he grows up to reclaim his throne from his murderous uncle Scar, backed by a beloved Elton John soundtrack.
One of the most popular cocktails in America, this tequila-based drink is made with lime juice and triple sec or Cointreau, typically served shaken or on the rocks in a glass with a salted rim.

Elected in 2008, this Illinois senator became the 44th President of the United States — the first African American to hold the office — and was awarded the Nobel Peace Prize during his first year in power.
Measured in hertz, this property of a wave describes the number of complete cycles that occur per second — it determines the pitch of a sound and, in the case of light waves, its color.

This rapper from Detroit, born Marshall Mathers, is the best-selling hip-hop artist of all time and won an Academy Award for Best Original Song in 2003 for 'Lose Yourself' from his semi-autobiographical film '8 Mile.'

This NBC mockumentary sitcom, adapted from a British series by Ricky Gervais, is set at the Dunder Mifflin paper company in Scranton, Pennsylvania, and starred Steve Carell as the painfully oblivious boss Michael Scott.

Held annually on the first Saturday in May at Churchill Downs in Louisville, this thoroughbred horse race is the first leg of the Triple Crown and is nicknamed 'The Most Exciting Two Minutes in Sports.'
Spanning eleven time zones and sharing borders with more countries than any other nation, this country is the world's largest by total area and has Moscow as its capital.

In this 1991 thriller, FBI trainee Clarice Starling seeks the help of incarcerated psychiatrist Dr. Hannibal Lecter to catch a serial killer — making it one of only three films in history to win Oscars for all five major categories.
Made by fermenting soybeans with salt and koji mold, this Japanese paste is the base for one of the country's most beloved soups, traditionally served with tofu, seaweed, and green onions.

Held in August 1969 on Max Yasgur's dairy farm in upstate New York, this three-day music festival attracted roughly 400,000 attendees and featured performances by Jimi Hendrix, Janis Joplin, and The Who.

Unlike fission, which splits atoms apart, this process combines two light atomic nuclei to form a heavier one, releasing enormous amounts of energy — the same reaction that powers the sun and every other star.

This rapper and producer from Compton, California co-founded Death Row Records, launched the careers of Snoop Dogg and Eminem, later founded Beats Electronics, and sold the headphone company to Apple for $3 billion.

Set on Madison Avenue in 1960s New York City, this AMC drama stars Jon Hamm as the brilliant but mysterious ad executive Don Draper and is celebrated for its meticulous period detail and exploration of the American Dream.
This quarterback played for the New England Patriots and Tampa Bay Buccaneers and won a record seven Super Bowl championships, widely cementing his status as the greatest player in NFL history.

Built across 118 small islands connected by over 400 bridges, this northeastern Italian city is famous for its gondolas, its annual Carnival festival, and the gradual sinking that threatens its long-term survival.

In this 1985 John Hughes film, five high school students from different social cliques — the brain, the athlete, the basket case, the princess, and the criminal — spend a Saturday detention together and break down their social walls.
This deep-fried dough pastry, generously dusted with powdered sugar, is the signature treat of New Orleans and is traditionally served alongside café au lait at the historic Café Du Monde.

On December 1, 1955, this Montgomery, Alabama seamstress refused to give up her bus seat to a white passenger, an act of quiet defiance that ignited the Montgomery Bus Boycott and galvanized the American civil rights movement.
Launched by Epic Games in 2017, this free-to-play battle royale game drops up to 100 players onto a shrinking island where they scavenge for weapons and build structures to be the last one standing.
This English singer-songwriter's second album '21,' released in 2011 and featuring the worldwide hit 'Rolling in the Deep,' became one of the best-selling albums in UK and US chart history.

This San Francisco Giants outfielder holds the all-time MLB career home run record with 762, surpassing Hank Aaron's mark of 755 in 2007, though his legacy remains clouded by performance-enhancing drug allegations.

Located on the northwestern shore of Lake Ontario, this Canadian city is the country's largest, home to the CN Tower and the Hockey Hall of Fame, and is frequently called one of the most multicultural cities in the world.
Starring the late Chadwick Boseman as the king of the fictional African nation of Wakanda, this 2018 Marvel film was the first superhero movie ever nominated for the Academy Award for Best Picture.

Introduced by McDonald's in 1968, this burger stacks two beef patties with special sauce, lettuce, cheese, pickles, and onions on a three-part sesame-seed bun, and has become one of the most recognized foods on the planet.

This English naturalist, who sailed on the HMS Beagle in the 1830s and observed wildlife on the Galápagos Islands, published 'On the Origin of Species' in 1859 and transformed humanity's understanding of life on Earth.
Known as the 'universal recipient,' this blood type can receive red blood cells from donors of any ABO and Rh blood group, making it the most flexible type to match for transfusions.
Born Benito Antonio Martínez Ocasio in Puerto Rico, this Latin trap and reggaeton artist became the most-streamed artist on Spotify globally in 2020, 2021, and 2022 — three consecutive years.
Released on Netflix in 2015, this true-crime documentary series sparked worldwide debate about the American justice system through the intertwined cases of Steven Avery and his nephew Brendan Dassey.
This British Formula One driver won seven World Championship titles between 2008 and 2020, and holds all-time records for the most race wins and the most pole positions in F1 history.

Completely encircled by Italy and covering just 61 square kilometers, this tiny republic on the slopes of Mount Titano claims to be the world's oldest constitutional republic, founded by tradition in 301 AD.
alternateAnswers: most serene republic of san marino

questions.question: In this 1999 sci-fi film by the Wachowskis, a computer hacker named Neo discovers that the reality everyone perceives is a simulated prison designed by machines, and joins a rebel group fighting to free humanity.
This sweet Italian liqueur, flavored with almonds and apricot pits, is a key ingredient in the Amaretto Sour and Alabama Slammer cocktails, and is most famously sold under the brand name Disaronno.

On November 9th of this year, the Berlin Wall — which had divided East and West Germany for 28 years — fell, symbolizing the collapse of the Iron Curtain and marking the effective end of the Cold War.

The most abundant metal in Earth's crust, this lightweight silvery element with the chemical symbol Al is used in everything from soda cans to aircraft fuselages and was once so scarce it was considered more precious than gold.

The world's largest and heaviest living bird, this flightless African native can sprint at up to 45 miles per hour and lays the largest eggs of any living bird species, each weighing up to three pounds.

Created by Stan Lee and Steve Ditko and first appearing in 1962, this Marvel superhero from Queens, New York gained his powers from a radioactive spider bite and lives by the motto 'with great power comes great responsibility.'
